name: It's Calm: Stunning Spaces to Get Some Peace

text.text: It's Calm: Stunning Spaces to Get Some Peace

Sometimes big city living can feel like riding a bucking bronco who's just been told their ass is looking a bit fat. Occasionally, we feel the need to dismount and head somewhere calm and quiet, where we can partake in a little reflection and introspection and maybe even shed a couple of tears now it's become okay to cry in public. This is a collection of stunning and serene places where you can turn the tempo of your day right down.

tip.text: This beautiful bit of church is the type of setting film producers have wet dreams about. It's London's oldest parish church, built in 1123 at a time when the church-building business was booming. Over the years, it's survived unscathed from the Great Fire of London, the Blitz and even the filming of Transformers: The Last Knight to remain an ornate, wondrous gem - the Priory Church is where that staggering vaulted ceiling is found. Choir performances, concerts and the like take place here, with a £5 entrance fee unless you're there for religious reasons.

text.text: This beautiful bit of church is the type of setting film producers have wet dreams about. It's London's oldest parish church, built in 1123 at a time when the church-building business was booming. Over the years, it's survived unscathed from the Great Fire of London, the Blitz and even the filming of Transformers: The Last Knight to remain an ornate, wondrous gem - the Priory Church is where that staggering vaulted ceiling is found. Choir performances, concerts and the like take place here, with a £5 entrance fee unless you're there for religious reasons.

tip.text:
Try and say BAPS Shri Swaminarayan Mandir five times really fast. This is one of London's real wonders: a sanctuary of vibrant Hindu worship in an incredible temple that's a masterpiece of Indian design. It looks like a strange apparition, and yet it's real. Real and glorious.

Made in the traditional north Indian style, it was the first of its kind to be built in the Western world and was painstakingly built. And we really mean that - 5,000 tonnes of stone was hand-carved by more than 1,500 skilled artisans at 14 different sites around India into 26,300 pieces. They were then assembled like a giant three-dimensional jigsaw puzzle within two and a half years.

The resulting piece of architecture is a dazzler, with intricate marble and wooden carvings everywhere you look. You can come here for a traditional Hindu prayer ceremony, learn about the world’s oldest living faith from the ‘Understanding Hinduism’ exhibition, or just come for a meditative stroll around the grounds.

text.text:
This is one of London's real wonders: a sanctuary of vibrant Hindu worship in an incredible temple that's a masterpiece of Indian design. It looks like a strange apparition, and yet it's gloriously real. 

Made in the traditional north Indian style, it was the first of its kind to be built in the Western world, with intricate marble and wooden carvings everywhere you look. You can come here for a traditional Hindu prayer ceremony, learn about the world’s oldest living faith from the ‘Understanding Hinduism’ exhibition, or just take a meditative stroll around the grounds.

tip.text:
You've got your institutions, and then the next level is Victoria & Albert Museum: one of the largest museums in the world dedicated to decorative art and design. Someone once likened it to 'an extremely capacious handbag' and that seems kinda fitting. There are over 145 galleries across seven floors full of all sorts: furniture, ceramics, sculpture, paintings, posters, metalwork, glass, textiles and dress. They're divided into four main departments: 1) Asia, 2) Furniture, Textiles and Fashion, 3) Sculpture, Metalwork, Ceramics and Glass, and 4) Word & Image.

There are really so many wonders here that it's hard to know where to start, but definitely worth a look is the Cast Courts, two huge galleries dedicated to casts of post-classical European sculpture and the lavish gallery cafe. You could spend all day at this place perusing the free collections and not even have seen a third of it. So you may well have to come back.

text.text:
One of the world's largest museums might not seem the most logical place to get away from it all but, with 145 galleries at our last count (that was a fun day), there are plenty of quieter, more tranquil spaces where people don't get to. 

In one such space, in the Islamic Middle East collection, is the Ardabil Carpet - the world's oldest dated rug. This intricate, single integrated design is lit up every half an hour to preserve its rich colours. Sitting on a bench here and marvelling at this beautiful piece of art amidst the high-ceilinged architecture of the V&A could very well lead to something deep within.

tip.text:
Built between 1714 and 1729 and designed by Nicholas Hawksmoor, this is one of London's most distinctive, powerful and original bits of building. It's an impressive looker and there's no mistaking, with its Gothic-looking tower seemingly reaching high for the sky (and potentially a little phallic) - an architectural blend of Italian, classical and Palladian stylings.

Formerly sitting on the boundary between the fat cats of the city and the poverty of the East End, it's been restored to its pre-1850 grandeur and now, along with its Anglican church functionality, hosts concerts, courses and social events. It's open during the day for a bit of contemplation, aside from when private events are on.

text.text:
Built between 1714 and 1729, this is one of London's most distinctive, powerful and original bits of building. It's an impressive looker and there's no mistaking, with a Gothic-looking tower seemingly reaching high for the sky (and potentially a little phallic) - an architectural blend of Italian, Classical and Palladian stylings. 

Formerly sitting on the boundary between the fat cats of the City and the poverty of the East End, it's been restored to its pre-1850 splendour and is open during the day for a bit of peaceful contemplation.

tip.text: This beautiful Tibetan Buddhist centre in Bermondsey offers heaps of classes and courses for scurrying rat racers, ranging from the importance of ethics, to an introduction to meditation, and training in lucid dreaming. While many of the courses are rooted in traditional Tibetan Buddhism, they do also offer classes like ‘Stress Less’ - a course which responds to the stress experienced by people living in big cities. They believe that commuting, media harassment and advertising for hair loss serums on the tube is making us all silly in the brain - learn to let it all go here.

text.text: This beautiful Tibetan Buddhist centre in Bermondsey is the kind of place we wish existed in every neighbourhood. It offers plenty of classes and courses for scurrying rat racers, ranging from the importance of ethics, to an introduction to meditation, to training in lucid dreaming. It's a place of calm for Buddhists and non-Buddhists alike, with a lovely Tibetan Tea Room and small reading library with plenty of comfy seating - often key to a true unwinding.

tip.text:
If this place could talk, it would probably never shut up about all the stuff it's seen. Built in the late 12th century by the Knights Templar - a crusading bunch of monks akin to a medieval SAS team, it's seen plenty over the years including the signing of the Magna Carta and the potentially more momentous filming of The Da Vinci Code.

The beautiful Gothic-Romanesque structure is set amongst the greenery, courtyards and ancient buildings of the Inns of Court. Look out for nine life-sized marble effigies of famous Knights Templars, atmospheric choral concerts and organ recitals. Come on a quiet day, you'll also find a bit of tranquillity. Entry is £5 unless you're there for religious reasons.

text.text:
If this place could talk, it would probably never shut up about all the stuff it's seen. Built in the late 12th century by the Knights Templar - a crusading bunch of monks akin to a medieval SAS team - it's seen plenty over the years including the signing of the Magna Carta and the similarly momentous filming of The Da Vinci Code.

The beautiful Gothic-Romanesque structure is set amongst the greenery, courtyards and ancient buildings of the Inns of Court. It can be popular with the tourists, but come on a quiet day and you'll certainly find a little tranquillity. Entry is £5 unless you're there for religious reasons.

tip.text:
From the outside you're thinking, sure just a regular old church. But then you get inside and wham! An interior to cause the eyes to widen and maybe, just maybe, the mouth to open. Little-known architect Christopher Wren designed this one and the domed roof, a visual splendour you could lose yourself in for hours, is actually the same design as the one at St Paul's.

Other fun facts include that this was the birthplace of the Samaritans, it got really messed up during the Great Fire of London, and it has twelve Corinthian columns. It's open during the day apart from when private events are on, whilst organ recitals, evensong and lunchtime recitals fill the lovely space with lovely noise.
